main.head: Macron latest: Under-fire French leader returns from ski trip with Paris in flames

EMMANUEL MACRON was forced to cut short his skiing trip for an emergency meeting with ministers after yellow vest protesters ransacked shops and hurled smoke bombs and bricks at police officers across Paris.

graphic.alt: Emmanuel Macron was forced to cut short his skiing trip for an emergency meeting with ministers

main.p: Thugs were seen vandalising businesses on the upmarket Champs-Elysees avenue on the 18th straight weekend of protests which were characterised with a sharp increase in violence. Fires were started in nearby streets, with at least one car erupting in flames. The fire department said two people had to be rescued and eleven people suffered minor injuries. High-end restaurant Fouquet’s, a popular eatery amongst politicians and celebrities, was ransacked by protesters who overturned chairs, tables and smashed the windows.
main.head: Related articles
main.p: Designer stores including Hugo Boss and Lacoste were also vandalised, along with a bank, another restaurant and several newsstands.
The French president is now holding an emergency meeting at the interior ministry, his office has confirmed, after he cut short his skiing trip in the Pyrenees to return to Paris.
French Prime Minister Edouard Philippe, who visited the scene said: “Like the vast majority of French people, I feel very angry today.
“Today's actions are not the work of protesters, but of looters, arsonists and criminals.

“No cause justifies this violence.”
In a statement, the national police denounced the “mindless violence, cowardly attacks” and stressed their determination to reinforce public order against “provocateurs and vandals”.
Interior Minister Christophe Castaner said thugs looking for trouble had infiltrated the demonstrations.
“Let there be no doubt: they are looking for violence and are there to sow chaos in Paris,” Mr Castaner said.

main.p: Police used tear gas, water cannons and batons to push back protesters.
Mr Castaner said there were more than 1,500 “ultra violent” people out looking for trouble.
He said: “They decided, perhaps as a swansong, to come attack - and I use their words - Paris.
“I’ve given instructions to the police this morning for great firmness so that nothing slips by."

main.p: Fights broke out on the Champs Elysee before midday.
More than 120 protesters were arrested.
An officer at the scene said: “Gangs are targeting police, and carrying out numerous acts of vandalism.
“Fires are being lit, including in cars.

main.p: “Thousands are arriving all over the city, and we are already extremely stretched.”
Police estimate around 10,000 people took part in Saturday’s Paris protests, a stark increase compared with similar demonstrations in recent weeks.
A total of 32,300 are believed to have taken to the streets across France.
